On cover: "...this classic story shows how a young woman can overcome adversity and find true happiness. After her uncle dies, young Jane Eyre is terribly mistreated by her aunt and cousins. She is quickly sent away to a girls' school, where life is not much better. But Jane loves books and learning, and she becomes the first in her class. She goes on to teach, then takes a position with Mr. Rochester, working as a governess. At his mansion, life changes dramatically".
"Masterwork Books is a division of Kidsbooks, Inc."

Kevin James, Leah Remini, Jerry Stiller.

Carrie, afraid that their marriage has gotten boring, signs them up for a class at the community college. Thinking that will make them more intellectual, she chooses a class on the Victorian novel. As she delves into Jane Eyre with relish, Doug can't even get through the Cliffs Notes. To make matters worse, Doug feels that he has to pretend to enjoy the book, the class and becoming educated -- basically everything he hates.

a collection of one-act dramatizations of famous stories and books for royalty-free performance and reading.

Plays for acting: Rip van Winkle, by W. Irving. Jane Eyre, by C. Brontë. The importance of being earnest, by O. Wilde. The transferred ghost, by F. R. Stockton. The rivals, by R. B. Sheridan. The flying Dutchman, by H. Heine. The bishop's candlesticks, by V. Hugo (from Les miserables). Wuthering Heights, by E. Brontë.--Plays for reading: Around the world in eighty days, by J. Verne. The Count of Monte Christo, by A. Dumas. A Christmas carol, by C. Dickens. Through the looking-glass, by L. Carroll. The kidnapping of David Balfour, by R. L. Stevenson (from Kidnapped). The man without a country, by E. E. Hale. Enoch Arden, by Alfred, Lord Tennyson. The Swiss family Robinson, by J. Wyss.

Great authors of the Western literary tradition

pt. 1. Introduction and the literature of ancient Greece and Jerusalem: lecture 1. The value of literature ; lecture 2. The interpretation of literature ; lecture 3. Introduction to Homer ; lecture 4. Challenging the heroic code ; lecture 5. Alpha and Omega ; lecture 6. Introduction to the Odysseus ; lecture 7. The uses of enchantment ; lecture 8. Homecoming ; lecture 9. The book of Job ; lecture 10. Plato and Poetry -- pt. 2. The literature of ancient Greece and Rome: lecture 1. Introduction to the Oresteia ; lecture 2. The sophoclean hero ; lecture 3. Complex Oedipus ; lecture 4. The bacchae ; lecture 5. Thucydides and the dawn of history ; lecture 6. Aristophanes and very old jokes ; lecture 7. Introduction to Virgil ; lecture 8. Aenaes, a new kind of hero ; lecture 9. Ovid and the Metomorphoses ; The Neronian way of death -- pt. 3. Medieval literature and the birth of English: lecture 1. Studying the literature of the past ; lecture 2. Some conventions of medieval literature ; lecture 3. The English language, then and now ; lecture 4. Beowulf and Old English poetry ; lecture 5. The song of Roland ; lecture 6. Medieval romance and the stories of Arthur ; lecture 7. The troubadours ; lecture 8. The romance of the rose ; lecture 9. The poet of Sir Gawain and the green knight ; lecture 10. Italian poets of the fourteenth century ; lecture 11. Chaucer, Troilus and Criseyde ; lecture 12. Chaucer, The Canterbury tales -- pt. 4. The literature of the Renaissance: lecture 1. Introduction to Renaissance literature ; lecture 2. Dante's life and times ; lecture 3. Dante's literary antecedents ; lecture 4. Erasmus, In praise of folly ; lecture 5. Introduction to Shakespeare ; lecture 6. Richard III, actor as villain ; lecture 7. Hamlet and the perplexing world ; lecture 8. Twelfth night and Shakespearean comedy ; lecture 9. Cervantes, Don Quixote ; lecture 10. Milton, Paradise lost ; lecture 11. Milton, Paradise lost II ; lecture 12. Pascal, Pensees -- pt. 5. Neo-Classical and romantic literature: lecture 1. Introduction to 18th-century literature ; lecture 2. Racine, Phaedre ; lecture 3. Moliere, The misanthrope ; lecture 4. Defoe, Robinson Crusoe ; lecture 5. Defoe, Moll Flanders ; lecture 6. Voltaire, Candide ; lecture 7. Swift, Gulliver's travels ; lecture 8. Sterne, Tristram Shandy ; lecture 9. Rousseau, Connfessions ; lecture 10. Goethe, The sorrows of young Werther ; lecture 11. Goether, Faust ; lecture 12. Stendhal, The red and the black -- pt. 6. The nineteenth century, realism and naturalism: lecture 1. Introduction to 19th-century literature ; lecture 2. Balzac, Pere Goriot ; lecture 3. Austen, Pride and prejudice ; lecture 4. Dickens, Bleak house ; lecture 5. Melville, Moby Dick ; lecture 6. Bronte, Jane Eyre ; lecture 7. Flauber, Madame Bovary ; lecture 8. Tolstoy, The death of Ivan Ilych ; lecture 9. Ibsen ; lecture 10. Strindberg ; lecture 11. Conrad, Heart of darkness ; lecture 12. Mann, Death in Venice -- pt. 7. The twentieth century, modernism and existentialism: lecture 1. Introduction to 20th-century literature ; lecture 2. Kafka, Short stories ; lecture 3. Kafka, Short stories ; lecture 4. Proust, Rememberance of things past ; lecture 5. Joyce, Ulysses ; lecture 6. Woolf To the lighthouse ; lecture 7. Faulkner, The sound and the fury ; lecture 8. Faulkner, Absalom, Absalom ; lecture 9. Sartre, Nausea ; lecture 10. Camus, The plague ; lecture 11. Beckett, drama of alienation.
do not retain if CD is acquired

pt. 1a. Drama: lecture 1. Why literature, civilization and its discontent ; lecture 2. Oedipus the King and the name of Greek tragedy ; lecture 3. Fate and free will, reading for signs in Oedipus ; lecture 4. Self-making vs. self-discovery in Oedipus ; lecture 5. The interpretive afterlife in Oedipus ; lecture 6. Shakespeare's Othello, tragedy of marriage and state ; lecture 7. Poison in the ear, or the dismantling of Othello ; lecture 8. Rethinking Othello, race, gender, and subjectivity ; lecture 9. French theatre and Moliere's comedy of vices ; lecture 10. Tartuffe and varieties of imposture -- pt. 1b. Drama: lecture 11. Religious hypocrisy, beyond comedy ; lecture 12. Georg Bruchner, physician, revolutionary, playwright ; lecture 13. Woyzeck the proletarian murderer, unaccomodated man ; lecture 14. Woyzeck and visionary theater ; lecture 15. Strindberg's father, patriarchy in trouble ; lecture 16. Marriage, theatrical agon or Darwinian struggle? ; lecture 17. The father, from theater of power to power of theater ; lecture 18. Beckett's Godot, Chaplinesque or post-nuclear? ; lecture 19. Beckett and the comedy of undoing ; lecture 20. Godot absent, Didi and Gogo present -- pt. 2a. Poetry: lecture 21. Study of literature, approaches, encounters, departures ; lecture 22. Shakespeare's sonnets, the glory of poetry ; lecture 23. The shape of love and death in Shakespeare's sonnets ; lecture 24. Innocence and experience in William Blake ; lecture 25. Bleakean fables of desire ; lecture 26. Blake, visionary poet ; lecture 27. Whitman and the making of an American bard ; lecture 28. Myself in Whitman's 19th-century American hero ; lecture 29. Form and flux, openness and anxiety in Whitman's poetry ; lecture 30. Emily Dickinson, the prophetic voice from the margins -- pt. 2b. Poetry: lecture 31. Dickinson and the poetry of consciousness ; lecture 32. Dickinson, death and beyond ; lecture 33. Baudelaire, the setting of the romantic sun ; lecture 34. Baudelaire's poetry of modernism and metropolis ; lecture 35. Robert Frost, the wisdom of the people ; lecture 36. Frost, the darker view ; lecture 37. Wallace Stevens and the modernist movement ; lecture 38. Stevens and the post-romantic imagination ; lecture 39. Adrienne Rich and the poetry of protest ; lecture 40. Rich's project, diving into the wreck of Western culture -- pt. 3a. Narrative: lecture 41. The lives of the word, reading today ; lecture 42. Chretien de Troyes' Yvain, growing up in the middle ages ; lecture 43. Yvain's theme, ignorant armies clash by night ; lecture 44. The picaresque novel, satire, filth and hustling ; lecture 45. Francisco Quevedo's Swindler, the word on the street ; lecture 46. Daniel Defoe's plain style and the new world order ; lecture 47. Moll Flanders and the self-made woman ; lecture 48. Matter and spirit in Defoe ; lecture 49. Dickens, the novel as moral institution ; lecture 50. Pip's progress, from blacksmith to snob and back ; lecture 51. Riddles of identity in Great expectations ; lecture 52. Charlotte Bronte and the bildungsroman -- pt. 3b. Narrative: lecture 53. Jane Eyre, Victorian bad girl makes good ; lecture 54. The madwoman in the attic, 19th-century bills coming due ; lecture 55. Melville's Bartleby and the genesis of character ; lecture 56. Bartleby, Christ on Wall Street? ; lecture 57. Franz Kafka's Metamorphosis, sacrifice or power game? ; lecture 58. Kafka's In the penal colony, the writing machine ; lecture 59. Faulkner's The bear, stories of white and black ; lecture 60. The bear, American myth or American history? ; lecture 61. Tracking the bear, or learning to read ; lecture 62. Alice Walker's Celie, the untold story ; lecture 63. Ideology as vision in The color purple ; lecture 64. Reconceiving center and margin.

Reprint of the 1935 ed., which was a revision of the work first published in 1906 under title: The persons and places of the Brontë novels.
